awd_titl_txt: Theory of Light Hydrogenlike Bound States:  High Order Corrections in Muonic and Electronic Atoms and Ions
awd_abstract_narration:
High precision quantum electrodynamics of hydrogenlike bound states is an active field of theoretical research, motivated both by the spectacular experimental progress and the intellectual challenge.  Despite significant progress in the theory of light, hydrogenlike bound states, there are a number of challenging problems in this field that are addressed in this project. Search for a theoretical explanation of the discrepancy between the value of the proton charge radius obtained from the experiment with muonic hydrogen and the proton charge radius derived from hydrogen spectroscopy and electron-proton scattering is one of the main objectives. Improvement of the theory of the Lamb shift in muonic hydrogen and deuterium, and in light muonic helium ions is planned. Other objectives include calculation of polarizability contributions to the Lamb shift and hyperfine splitting in muonic atoms and ions, and of other unknown corrections in muonic atoms. Further development and improvement of the theory of hyperfine splitting in muonium and the theory of the Lamb shift in electronic hydrogen are among the goals of this project.

The theoretical results obtained in this research will find applications in the analysis of the forthcoming experimental results on muonic and electronic atoms and ions. This analysis will result in more precise values of the fundamental physical constants, especially the proton radius, as well as radii of the deuteron and alpha particles. These values will find applications in metrology and nuclear physics. New theoretical expressions will be used in the new CODATA analysis of the fundamental physical constants, and in its turn CODATA compilations of the fundamental constants are used in every science classroom, and in numerous fields of science and engineering, from fundamental research to consumer electronics. Graduate and undergraduate students participating in this research will acquire research, computer, problem solving, and presentation skills. Research activity of a graduate student is expected to lead to a PhD thesis. This project will promote international collaboration, as collaboration with foreign scientists is planned. The results of the proposed research will be published in refereed journals, will be presented at domestic and international conferences and workshops, and will be used in teaching graduate courses.

por.por_cntn:
High precision quantum electrodynamics of hydrogenlike bound states is an active field of theoretical research motivated both by the spectacular experimental progress and the intellectual challenge. Despite significant progress in the theory of light hydrogenlike bound states there is a number of challenging problems in this field that are addressed in this project. Objectives of this project include search for a theoretical explanation of the discrepancy between the value of the proton charge radius obtained from the experiment with muonic hydrogen and the proton charge radius derived from hydrogen spectroscopy and electron-proton scattering. They also include improvement of the theory of hyperfine splitting in muonium (an atom consisting of a positive muon and an electron) and positronium (an atom consisting of a positron and an electron). In the work on this project weak interaction contributions to hyperfine splitting and Lamb shift in muonic hydrogen, muonic deuterium, muonic tritium, and muonic helium ion were calculated. These results were already used for comparison between theory and the latest experimental results. The goal of calculation of high order corrections to hyperfine splitting in muonium is extraction of a more precise value of the electron-muon mass ratio from the experimental data. In this project we calculated three-loop nonrecoil and radiative-recoil corrections to hyperfine splitting in muonium. These results are  a significant new step toward the goal of reducing the theoretical error of hyperfine splitting in muonium below 10 Hz. We also calculated hard nonlogarithmic corrections to hyperfine splitting in positronium of order mα^7. These results open a new stage in the research on positronium hyperfine splitting and in comparison between theory and experiment on hyperfine splitting in positronium.
 
The theoretical results obtained in this research already found applications in the analysis of the latest experimental results on muonic and electronic atoms and ions. The results obtained in this research allow to obtain a more precise value of electron-muon mass ratio from experimental results on muonium hyperfine splitting. New theoretical expressions obtained in the work on this project were used in the latest 2014 CODATA adjustment of the fundamental physical constants, that resulted in new more precise values of the fundamental physical constants. In its turn the CODATA compilations of the fundamental constants are widely used in every science classroom, and in numerous fields of science and engineering, from fundamental research to consumer electronics.This project promoted international collaboration, some results were obtained in collaboration with foreign scientists. The results of this research were published in refereed journals, were presented at international conferences and workshops, and were used in teaching graduate courses.
